race.name: Mid-State Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: Gates, switchbacks, and quiet farm country gravel in central Pennsylvania.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Pennsylvania countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Pennsylvania event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Mid-State Gravel Grinder is a local event in Pennsylvania‚Äîrolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Pennsylvania countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Pennsylvania gravel race. Worth it for Pennsylvania/Northeast riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Pennsylvania‚Äîyes, it's good value. If you're traveling‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Pennsylvania races: Dirty Kanza PA, Trans-Sylvania Epic.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Central PA has good lodging options.
logistics.food: Central PA has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Pennsylvania rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Starting at Mid-State Airport on Airport Road works fine ‚Äî 7:00 AM registration, 8:30 AM close, 9:00 AM start keeps things moving. Aid stations at miles 16 and 26 for the half course with cutoff at noon. Lynn Botelho had her nutrition dialed in and the basic setup delivered what she needed.

length.explanation: The 48-mile half course hits that middle distance sweet spot ‚Äî long enough for strategy but short enough for newcomers. Evan McGregor executed a patient race plan, staying with stronger riders until the decisive Tram Road descent. HoboStephen completed his first-ever bike race here after just four months of cycling. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: The baby head gravel descent spans 1-1.5 miles and demands respect ‚Äî Lynn Botelho's race strategy was simply 'Stay Upright' rather than push speed. Multiple gates require dismounting, plus nearly U-turns and embedded rock on Tram Road where Evan McGregor took three minutes off his previous descent time. Less technical than The Mid South. As Evan McGregor puts it: "I took the lead on Tram into its climb and from there I pushed a high pace to discourage any attacking, but without going over the line. On the descents and corners, I went hard to keep a lead spot..."

elevation.explanation: At 3,458 feet over 48 miles, Lynn Botelho calls this 'relatively flat course for us in PA' ‚Äî which tells you everything about Pennsylvania gravel standards. The climbing is consistent enough that Evan McGregor could use descending skills rather than raw power to create his winning 30+ second gap. Less climbing than The Mid South. As Evan McGregor puts it: "I took the lead on Tram into its climb and from there I pushed a high pace to discourage any attacking, but without going over the line. On the descents and corners, I went hard to keep a lead spot..."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 82¬∞F and lows of 64¬∞F, with a 61% chance of rain on any given day. The August date shows in the DNF rates ‚Äî the 70-mile course had 20.5% DNFs versus just 2.8% on the shorter distance. Heat and humidity take their toll on the longer efforts, though the 9:00 AM start helps beat the worst conditions. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Philipsburg sits around 1,500 feet ‚Äî zero altitude considerations for anyone. The bumpy airfield finish brings you right back to where you started at Mid-State Airport. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Course maps show dirt/gravel roads in red, paved in black through central Pennsylvania farm country. The route includes several gates to wiggle through and almost U-turns that break up the standard gravel rhythm. It's honest miles through honest terrain without trying to be more than it is.

prestige.explanation: This is a regional PA gravel race that barely registers on the national radar. No notable pro riders, no prize purse, no YouTube coverage ‚Äî just basic event listings on BikeReg and RaceRoster. They had to move the 2026 date to August 15th and start from an airport road address tells you everything about their draw power.

race_quality.explanation: The race exists and happens consistently, with 2025 and 2026 editions scheduled in Philipsburg. But zero course details, no aid station info, no cutoff times ‚Äî this screams bare-bones operation. When your entire race description is 'continue gravel races around Pennsylvania,' you're not setting the bar high.

experience.explanation: Evan McGregor describes balancing 'my role as husband and father fitting more in balance with my competitive nature' during race weekend. The event accommodates both newcomers like HoboStephen calling it 'perfect' and elites executing tactical racing on technical descents.

community.explanation: It's a local PA gravel scene event that keeps the regional riders busy in August. Listed across multiple platforms suggests some established community support, but the complete absence of rider chatter online is telling. You'll find your people, but don't expect deep connections or lasting friendships. As Lynn Botelho puts it: "Even more happy to see and talk to so many other BaseCamp people. Most happy for being part of this great community and being able to keep learning and improving."

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 50-100 riders, no field size data, no notable past winners, no pro presence whatsoever. This is weekend warrior territory through and through. If you're looking to test yourself against serious competition, keep looking ‚Äî this field won't challenge anyone beyond the local club level. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Evan McGregor's winning strategy puts it: "My pre-race plan took hold. Stick in, help keep the pace relatively high, and when we get to Tram Road, go for it."

value.explanation: You get multiple distance options, proper aid stations, and technical challenges that can decide races on descending skills. Part of the Trans-Sylvania series for points chasers, beginner-friendly enough for first-timers, with course features that reward bike handling over just power.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Airport start eliminates parking concerns, and central Pennsylvania keeps costs reasonable compared to destination events. One rider asked about 40mm tire clearance on their 2019 Crux, suggesting the terrain demands some equipment consideration but nothing exotic. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

citations.label: reddit.com: Rode In My First Bike Race Yesterday The Midstate

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Mid-State Gravel Grinder gravel race Central Pennsylvania

videos.title: Why Do Trans-sylvania Gravel Epic?
videos.description:
Riders at the 2022 edition of Trans-sylania Gravel Epic in central Pennsylvania talk about their favorite parts of the 4 day gravel stage race. 

https://www.tsegravel.com/

videos.title: Middle Creek Gravel Grinder 2019
videos.description: Completed my first gravel bike race/ride. The Middle Creek Gravel Grinder was a great race on a perfect day for cycling. While I've got a long way to go in regards to my training I'm excited to try another one and come back next year to improve my times. This is the medium gravel route - I'm nowhere near XL shape.

videos.title: Keystone Gravel 2021
videos.description: Course video from the 2021 Keystone Gravel Gravelduro near Jersey Shore, PA.  It was a perfect day and an epic course with over 10,000 feet of climbing in 80 miles.  This is not your ordinary gravel grinder!  No mass start this year.

Thinking about diving into gravel cycling? I've spent years making mistakes, testing gear, and refining my approach‚Äîso you don't have to. Here's what every new gravel cyclist needs to know before hitting the trails.

you ever buy something thinking it was

for reference if I was looking for bikes

small Tire high pressure will amplify

overanalyzing Geo charts focus on Tire
clearance and consider getting a bike
fit shipping a bike shouldn't feel like

tried you know the struggle is real

packing requirements and the crippling

they know what a derailer is they're a

mission to make shipping bikes as easy
as riding them woo thank you for that
step one go to bikeflights.com step two

three get your bike packed picked up and

stress and if you need a box
they've got you covered honestly it's
brilliant it goes from this to this it's
been a long time since I've been this
excited about three ply corrugated
cardboard save up to 40% on shipping
with the best protection for your bike
hit the link down below and let's get
your bike to where it needs to go minus
the
headache steel carbon aluminum titanium
I used to think material was everything
and over the last 25 years I've ridden
pretty much every material out there but
here's the thing there's one thing that
has an even bigger impact over the
handling and control of your bike we're
talking about tires larger tires with
lower pressure are going to have a more
dramatic effect over the handling
compliance and feel of your bike for the
dollar than any frame material will
especially if you're on a budget don't
stress about the perfect frame material
put that effort into getting a good set
of wheels and experimenting with some
tires hey what are your favorite tires
right
now people love throwing money at fancy

but nothing I mean nothing will improve
your ride experience more than getting a

do have a big impact it'll make you more

actually make up for a lower quality

wrap your head around easier
harder
simple this is how you can tell if a
bike brand is using bandwagon marketing
or gravel washing if a bike has a max
Tire clearance of 38 mm that's not a
gravel bike that's an endurance or
Allroad bike with some lazy marketing
any self-respecting gravel bike is going
to have a minimum Max clearance of 45 mm
and if you're riding any amount of
rugged terrain or would actually like to
run fenders I suggest looking for a
clearance at a minimum of 50 mm which
unfortunately is exactly why I rarely
run my titanium stinner minimal
clearance and no mounts for fenders
means I just don't ride it as much as I

videos.title: Trans-Sylvania Gravel Epic 2022 Stage 3 Rothrock Forest
videos.description:
With under 60miles and less than 100ft/mile of climbing this stage was fixing to be fast. Then add in some additional 2 day racers like Gordon and we were set to rip through Rothrock. This was the most scenic stage so far, Though, not in the sense of beautiful vistas because we were deep in the canopy most of the time. However, the thick old growth, damp roads, and deep green cover was putting off PNW vibes. 

A big group of 6 or so rolled early. Then stayed together until just after the aid. Eddie pushed up a stair stepping double track into a longer chunky descent. We got a gap over the top and likely extended it on the way down. From there it was 15 miles to the finish with no major climbs. 

Eddie tried to shake me on the final 5 min climb up into camp but I held on and led into the final corner, grabbing the W!

One more day!

These videos take a lot of  time to make and sometimes the adventures are expensive. If you feel like donating to encourage/help me offset costs, THANKYOU! Your contribution is greatly appreciated and gives me the resources to provide y'all more content. 
Venmo: www.venmo.com/u/Kerry-Werner-1
paypal: https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/kerrywerner

https://bike.shimano.com/en-US/home.html
https://www.konaworld.com
https://www.maxxis.com/tires/bicycle

videos.curation_reason: First-person race recap from a known gravel racer showing the competitive atmosphere and course conditions in central Pennsylvania.

quotes.text: This was the most scenic stage so far, though not in the sense of beautiful vistas because we were deep in the canopy most of the time. The thick old growth, damp roads, and deep green cover was putting off PNW vibes.

We were freaking cruising for the first 20 miles probably doing 20 to 24 miles an hour or something like that which means we were doing a lot of group racing had a big group of five or six, lots of drafting and being tactical today.
